articles.headline: Of Kiwis and Currencies: How a 2% Inflation Target Became Global Economic Gospel
articles.snippet: A target that started 25 years ago in New Zealand has become the gospel of governments worldwide. But critics say it leaves central banks with too little flexibility.
articles.abstract: A target that started 25 years ago in New Zealand has become the gospel of governments worldwide. But critics say it leaves central banks with too little flexibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes, decisions that shape the world’s economic future are made with great pomp and gain widespread attention. Other times, they are made through a quick, unanimous vote by members of the New Zealand Parliament who were eager to get home for Christmas.

articles.headline: Obama Vows a Response to Cyberattack on Sony
articles.snippet: President Obama said the U.S. would “respond proportionally” to the attack on Sony Pictures after the F.B.I. said it had extensive evidence that North Korea had organized it.
articles.abstract: President Obama said the U.S. would “respond proportionally” to the attack on Sony Pictures after the F.B.I. said it had extensive evidence that North Korea had organized it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Friday that the United States “will respond proportionally” against North Korea for its destructive cyberattacks on Sony Pictures, but he criticized the Hollywood studio for giving in to intimidation when it withdrew “The Interview,” the satirical movie that provoked the attacks, before it opened.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Michael S. Schmidt and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Delving Into Morass of Insider Trading
articles.snippet: Insider trading is a crime entirely defined by common law — an accumulation of cases and judicial precedents that date from the 1960s — and fitting a case into that thicket can be problematic.
articles.abstract: Insider trading is a crime entirely defined by common law — an accumulation of cases and judicial precedents that date from the 1960s — and fitting a case into that thicket can be problematic.
articles.lead_paragraph: We need an insider trading statute.

articles.headline: At U.S. Ports, Even Santa’s Bag Might Be Peeked Into
articles.snippet: For months, federal safety agents have been screening thousands of shipments of toys and other imports, looking for hazards in the nation’s holiday gifts.
articles.abstract: For months, federal safety agents have been screening thousands of shipments of toys and other imports, looking for hazards in the nation’s holiday gifts.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Dwarfed by towering stacks of boxes stuffed with toy cars, play sets and Christmas lights, federal safety agents armed with bulky lead detector guns and little else comb through mountains of shipments arriving at the nation’s ports.

articles.headline: McDonald’s Is Charged With Punishing Workers
articles.snippet: The National Labor Relations Board’s general counsel brought 78 charges against the fast-food company accusing it of retaliating against workers who protested for higher pay.
articles.abstract: The National Labor Relations Board’s general counsel brought 78 charges against the fast-food company accusing it of retaliating against workers who protested for higher pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: The National Labor Relations Board announced on Friday that its general counsel had brought 78 charges against McDonald’s and some of its franchise operators, accusing them of violating federal labor law in response to workers’ protests for higher wages around the country.

articles.headline: The Insurance Market Mystifies an Airbnb Host
articles.snippet: Dropped by one homeowners’ insurance company, an Airbnb host gets conflicting information from two others.
articles.abstract: Dropped by one homeowners’ insurance company, an Airbnb host gets conflicting information from two others.
articles.lead_paragraph: So let’s say you decided to place your home or a few rooms inside it among the million-plus listings that the rental site Airbnb now claims to have.

articles.headline: Crucible of Cuban Zeal Redefines Revolutionary
articles.snippet: Cárdenas, Cuba, which is home to Elián González, is a growing city of contrasts and contradictions.
articles.abstract: Cárdenas, Cuba, which is home to Elián González, is a growing city of contrasts and contradictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CÁRDENAS, Cuba — The home of Elián González is a simple affair — a one-story ranch, painted red, with a yin and yang symbol on an outer wall. His neighbors are quick to point to it with pride, along with their town, a place of revolutionary zeal ever since Fidel Castro successfully pushed the United States to return Elián to Cuba after the boy’s mother died at sea carrying him to Florida in 2000.

articles.headline: Investigators Said to Seek No Penalty for C.I.A.'s Computer Search
articles.snippet: A panel investigating the search of a computer network used by the Senate Intelligence Committee who were looking into the C.I.A.'s use of torture will suggest no punishments, officials said.
articles.abstract: A panel investigating the search of a computer network used by the Senate Intelligence Committee who were looking into the C.I.A.'s use of torture will suggest no punishments, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A panel investigating the Central Intelligence Agency’s search of a computer network used by staff members of the Senate Intelligence Committee who were looking into the C.I.A.’s use of torture will recommend against punishing anyone involved in the episode, according to current and former government officials.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Pakistan’s Old Curse
articles.snippet: There is little doubt that the Peshawar massacre has galvanized Pakistani society. The question is whether it can become a real turning point for a society plagued by violent divisions, culture wars and the strategic prerogatives of a powerful mil...
articles.abstract: There is little doubt that the Peshawar massacre has galvanized Pakistani society. The question is whether it can become a real turning point for a society plagued by violent divisions, culture wars and the strategic prerogatives of a powerful military.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Only a week ago, the Red Mosque seemed a nearly untouchable bastion of Islamist extremism in Pakistan, a notorious seminary in central Islamabad known for producing radicalized, and sometimes heavily armed, graduates.

articles.headline: Judge in Maryland Locks Up Youths and Rules Their Lives
articles.snippet: Juvenile court judges are given wide discretion to decide what is in a young offender’s best interest. Many, like Judge Herman C. Dawson, turn to incarceration.
articles.abstract: Juvenile court judges are given wide discretion to decide what is in a young offender’s best interest. Many, like Judge Herman C. Dawson, turn to incarceration.
articles.lead_paragraph: UPPER MARLBORO, Md. — “Judge Dawson, he don’t play,” a parent once said about Herman C. Dawson, the main juvenile court judge in Prince George’s County. And on this Tuesday morning, Judge Dawson was definitely not in a playing mood.

articles.headline: Fresh Doubt Over the Bailout of A.I.G.
articles.snippet: Documents produced after the trial put a new light on a government rescue that never went to a shareholder vote.
articles.abstract: Documents produced after the trial put a new light on a government rescue that never went to a shareholder vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The government is on thin ice and they know it,” a lawyer representing the Federal Reserve Bank of New York wrote in a private email on Sept. 17, 2008, as the federal bailout of the American International Group was being negotiated. “But who’s going to challenge them on this ground?”

articles.headline: YouTube’s Chief, Hitting a New ‘Play’ Button
articles.snippet: The site is a huge cultural force, but an unfulfilled economic one. Susan Wojcicki’s mission is to change that.
articles.abstract: The site is a huge cultural force, but an unfulfilled economic one. Susan Wojcicki’s mission is to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: This fall, Susan Wojcicki, the chief executive of YouTube, appeared on a panel at Vanity Fair’s inaugural technology conference in San Francisco. Sitting on the same stage at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts where Steve Jobs once introduced the iPad to the world, she discussed the future of the media with Richard Plepler, the chief executive of HBO.

articles.headline: U.S. Asks China to Help Rein In Korean Hackers
articles.snippet: As part of its response to the cyberattack on Sony Pictures, the Obama administration has asked China to assist in blocking North Korea’s ability to launch such attacks.
articles.abstract: As part of its response to the cyberattack on Sony Pictures, the Obama administration has asked China to assist in blocking North Korea’s ability to launch such attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has sought China’s help in recent days in blocking North Korea’s ability to launch cyberattacks, the first steps toward the “proportional response” President Obama vowed to make the North pay for the assault on Sony Pictures — and as part of a campaign to issue a broader warning against future hacking, according to senior administration officials.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Nicole Perlroth and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: If Not David to the U.S. Goliath, Cuba Asks What Its Role Is Now
articles.snippet: As Cubans absorb the news that the United States will begin normalizing relations with their government after more than five decades of hostility, they are contending with a rush of both excitement and uncertainty.
articles.abstract: As Cubans absorb the news that the United States will begin normalizing relations with their government after more than five decades of hostility, they are contending with a rush of both excitement and uncertainty.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — John F. Kennedy, who strengthened economic sanctions against Cuba in the early 1960s, has a whole room devoted to his sins. But the final exhibit, at the Italianate palace that houses the Museum of the Revolution on the edge of Old Havana, is “a gallery of cretins” — cartoon-style wooden cutouts of recent American presidents who are thanked for “helping us strengthen the Revolution.”
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Victoria Burnett

articles.headline: For Cubans in Miami, the Gulf to Their Homeland Narrows
articles.snippet: The re-establishment of U.S. diplomatic ties with Cuba brought widely different reactions in Miami, where first-generation exiles who remember Fidel Castro’s brutality mix with millennials for whom Cuba is more a cultural touchstone.
articles.abstract: The re-establishment of U.S. diplomatic ties with Cuba brought widely different reactions in Miami, where first-generation exiles who remember Fidel Castro’s brutality mix with millennials for whom Cuba is more a cultural touchstone.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Over a half-century, they have transformed what had been a sleepy, heat-drenched Southern town, infusing it with the rat-a-tat patter of Spanish in boardrooms and restaurants, the Cuban rhythms blasting from car radios, the linen guayaberas men don for parties and work, and the smells of mojo and picadillo wafting in the air.

articles.headline: Military Hospital Care Is Questioned; Next, Reprisals
articles.snippet: Physicians, nurses and medical workers at military hospitals say they have been brushed off, transferred, investigated and passed over for promotion after they pointed out problems with care.
articles.abstract: Physicians, nurses and medical workers at military hospitals say they have been brushed off, transferred, investigated and passed over for promotion after they pointed out problems with care.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. — Beyond conducting their periodic evaluation of Womack Army Medical Center, one of the military’s busiest hospitals, the inspectors who came here to Fort Bragg last March had a special task. A medical technologist had complained of dangerous lapses in the prevention of infections. The inspectors planned to follow up.

articles.headline: In China, a Rapid Jump to Mobile Advertising
articles.snippet: Next year, companies are expected to spend more money on digital advertising than on TV commercials in China.
articles.abstract: Next year, companies are expected to spend more money on digital advertising than on TV commercials in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Liu Xuelong, a television and documentary producer in Beijing, hasn’t used his television in years. He gets all of his entertainment on his iPhone 6 Plus, where he also taps a plethora of apps to buy plane tickets, pay bills, talk with clients.

articles.headline: Edith Ramirez Is Raising the F.T.C.’s Voice
articles.snippet: Edith Ramirez’s tenure as leader of the commission has been marked by an effort to bring the regulator into the public eye, directing particular attention on digital privacy and transactions.
articles.abstract: Edith Ramirez’s tenure as leader of the commission has been marked by an effort to bring the regulator into the public eye, directing particular attention on digital privacy and transactions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The New England Journal of Medicine is not a common venue for antitrust debates. But it was in that academic journal that Edith Ramirez, chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission, warned this month that mergers of physician practice groups could stifle competition.

articles.headline: How the Hacking at Sony Over ‘The Interview’ Became a Horror Movie
articles.snippet: Things have gone so deeply wrong so quickly, it is hard to keep track of all the mistakes that led us here, David Carr writes.
articles.abstract: Things have gone so deeply wrong so quickly, it is hard to keep track of all the mistakes that led us here, David Carr writes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kim Jong-un, who appears to be America’s newly self-appointed minister of culture, has decided that it is not enough that “The Interview,” the Seth Rogen film about North Korea that includes Mr. Kim’s assassination, will not be released. On Thursday, a message from the Guardians of Peace, the hacker group that breached the computer systems of Sony Pictures and warned against releasing the film, said “we want everything related to the movie, including its trailers, as well as its full version down from any website hosting them immediately.”

articles.headline: In 2008 Mumbai Attacks, Piles of Spy Data, but an Uncompleted Puzzle
articles.snippet: An investigation reveals how American, British and Indian agencies failed to pull together intelligence streams, including a plotter’s online activity, before attacks that Indians regard as their 9/11.
articles.abstract: An investigation reveals how American, British and Indian agencies failed to pull together intelligence streams, including a plotter’s online activity, before attacks that Indians regard as their 9/11.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2008, a 30-year-old computer expert named Zarrar Shah roamed from outposts in the northern mountains of Pakistan to safe houses near the Arabian Sea, plotting mayhem in Mumbai, India’s commercial gem.
articles.byline: By James Glanz, Sebastian Rotella and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Crunch Time for FedEx and UPS as Last-Minute Holiday Shipping Ramps Up
articles.snippet: FedEx and UPS are aiming to avoid last year’s chaos, when a late surge in shipments and bad weather left many gifts to be delivered late.
articles.abstract: FedEx and UPS are aiming to avoid last year’s chaos, when a late surge in shipments and bad weather left many gifts to be delivered late.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Donner Pass, the icy stretch of road that cuts through the Sierra Nevada mountains, is 2,000 miles away from FedEx’s world hub in Memphis.

articles.headline: After a Tumultuous Year at the Box Office, Hollywood Looks to 2015
articles.snippet: Hackers, changing movie habits and plain old duds — 2014 has not been kind to the industry. Attendance is driven by the movies themselves, but attendance this year may turn out to be the lowest since 2000.
articles.abstract: Hackers, changing movie habits and plain old duds — 2014 has not been kind to the industry. Attendance is driven by the movies themselves, but attendance this year may turn out to be the lowest since 2000.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The delay of major movies from Pixar and Universal. The pirating of “The Expendables 3” and “Annie” before their release. Warner Bros. suffering one dud after another. Hackers forcing the cancellation of a big Sony comedy.

articles.headline: He Sees You When You’re Sleeping, and Gives You Nightmares
articles.snippet: In Germany, misbehaving children had better watch out. The Krampus, a devilish goblin who tears through the streets as St. Nick’s evil counterpart, is making a comeback.
articles.abstract: In Germany, misbehaving children had better watch out. The Krampus, a devilish goblin who tears through the streets as St. Nick’s evil counterpart, is making a comeback.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Long before parents relied on the powers of Santa Claus to monitor their children’s behavior, their counterparts in Alpine villages called on a shaggy-furred, horned creature with a fistful of bound twigs to send the message that they had better watch out.

articles.headline: Cuba Seizures Now Present Opportunities
articles.snippet: Lawyers are scrambling to determine whether normalized relations with Cuba will create a chance to get compensation for lost properties now estimated to be worth nearly $7 billion.
articles.abstract: Lawyers are scrambling to determine whether normalized relations with Cuba will create a chance to get compensation for lost properties now estimated to be worth nearly $7 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It was a routine Saturday morning, almost two years after Fidel Castro took power in Cuba, when Lois and Roy Schechter went to check on their tobacco farm 100 miles west of their home in Havana.
